title: Why Beto and Buttigieg Pretend to Be Kennedys Magazine
content: So when two young 'outsiders' preach in platitudes it is Kennedy-esque and desirable ("This is an imprisonment the Democrats might choose to end at their peril.") But when the frontrunner, Bernie Sanders, says anything that could be described as ...'encapsulating the hopes and dreams of the electorate' or '...evoking themes that prove irresistible to liberals (generational change, a we-can-do-better scolding of a neglectful Republican stewardship, the need for national unity)' he is said to be vague and promising too much without being able to deliver (politispeak for: we like to talk about change, but don't actually want substantial change for the working poor). Perhaps, according to the author, Bernie is not 'vague enough not to alienate moderates who might be fearful of overreach.' So if you are some yound rich kid, you can AND SHOULD bullshit your way to the presidency with platitudes and mixed messaging that sounds good, but doesn't equate to anything real. But,if you are a life-long politician fighting for working class rights and dignity, with policies and agendas that would help those people you are just a 'rumpled-professor.' Nice.

title: Why Beto and Buttigieg Pretend to Be Kennedys Magazine
content: In policy terms, yes, pretty much so. The Kennedy's skated by on the family fortune, rhetoric as lofty as it was vague, and actual policies that had very negative long term (supply side tax cuts, 'going slow' on civil rights) and even short term (Bay of Pigs, Cuban Missile Crisis, Laos/Vietnam) consequences. For all of the hagiographic gushing, the irony is that Americans 40 and under (millinnials, gen-next--the two age groups who will be deciding elections for the next 40-50 years) already have a clear favorite, and it isn't a M$M-anointed reincarnation of a dead Kennedy; it's Sanders. Go figure.

title: Why Beto and Buttigieg Pretend to Be Kennedys Magazine
content: I like Buttigieg. Beto engages in way too much public navel-gazing . He speaks in broad platitudes; Buttigieg has sharp, specific responses.

title: Why Beto and Buttigieg Pretend to Be Kennedys Magazine
content: Not only do they not claim to be like Kennedys, I'm sure they are both running on their own merits which will or will not resonate with voters. The author sought a "hook" on which to base a theory for an article, but it's insulting and dismissive of these men and women running for office. I imagine there are far fewer of us that even experienced the Kennedy politicians than there are that did not. Stop trying to jam these candidates into prior molds. Let them be who they are, and let voters take it from there.

title: Why Beto and Buttigieg Pretend to Be Kennedys Magazine
content: The only reason there's any kind of narrative that draws parallels with Kennedys is because the media keeps pushing this BS. Voters don't care about this, and it's a waste of space for Politico to run this article. We need coverage on the policies proposed by the 2020 candidates, we need analysis on things like Medicare for all, Green New Deal, reparations, minimum wage, etc. The media drove the narrative in 2016 by focusing on the personal rather than proposed policies, and look where it got us. If a journalist isn't able or willing to lay out policies, and rise to the challenge of foregoing hyperbole and instead explain things in a way an 11-year-old can makes sense of, then they are doing nothing to contribute to 2020.
